Gone too soon

10/02/2015

Following the cancellation of In the Flesh, Liz Tresidder bemoans the BBC's lack of challenging programming for young people.

Image by

By undefined undefined

  When I told people that one of my favourite television shows, In the Flesh, had been cancelled, most of them looked at me and asked 'What? Again?' They weren't wrong. Statistically, the odds aren't looking great; this January, In the Flesh was killed off by BBC Three whilst The Hour (BBC 2) and Utopia (Channel 4) were given the axe after two short-lived series. Before me, the yawning abyss of television scheduling stretches, while Netflix hovers over my shoulder, waiting to relieve me of my sorrows. It's, frankly, a bit ridiculous. The BBC's attitude to drama shows is massively problematic; In the Flesh, The Hour and The Fades (another show that, whilst I never watched, is still largely indicative of the issue at hand) are all BAFTA-winning shows that were brutally cut short. Whilst In the Flesh was most-recently cancelled, The Hour makes for a telling precedent that helps explain the BBC's attitude to drama. Apparently, it was ground-breaking that The Hour even got a second series; it was the first original drama show to have two series on BBC 2. The press report announcing the show's cancellation said that the channel "have to make hard choices to bring new shows through." As all avid television fans will know, a cancellation of a favoured television show before its time is a traumatic affair usually requiring the traditional Victorian-era mourning period of wearing black for a year. Personally, it also means I remember what's said in press reports about the show well enough that when it's repeated, two years later, it comes back to haunt me somewhat. Should've kept that mourning wear. Specifically, in BBC Three's press release for In the Flesh's cancellation, the channel told audiences that "there is only budget for one original drama series a year on the channel" and that they "have to make hard choices to bring new shows through." I'm not sure what kind of 'hard choices' the BBC is repeatedly making, but part of me feels like it's making the wrong ones. If you haven't heard of In the Flesh, its crudest (most popular) label is usually 'gay zombie drama'. To put it more eloquently, In the Flesh is a show about the undead being re-introduced into British society through the NHS, following the main character, Kieren (played by Luke Newberry, who was BAFTA-nominated for the role. There were a lot of BAFTA nominations chucked at this show. Remind me why it was cancelled again, BBC? Oh, right. Hard choices.) as he negotiates family life and the return of the love of his life, Rick, from the dead. A basic summation, however, does the show an injustice. In the Flesh explored - specifically, at least - themes of sexuality, oppression and depression. In a broader interpretation, In the Flesh allowed its premise to become a metaphor for a myriad of social problems; the show's main appeal was that it become something of a cipher, allowing the audience to transfer issues they may be struggling with onto the narrative. The representations of sexuality and mental health, topics generally assigned to supporting characters in BBC shows or heavy-handedly (usually offensively) hammered into an episode of Sherlock or Doctor Who by Steven Moffat, are no doubt what made the show so popular. In fact, it's arguable that this is also what made the show so internationally appealing. Young people from around the world have been clamouring for a move away from traditional heteronormative narratives in television and film, yet the media repeatedly fail to meet the most basic demands for diversity. In the Flesh was a show that went some way to give these viewers some representation in its short-lived run.
The media repeatedly fail to meet the most basic demands for diversity
It's no coincidence that The Hour and In the Flesh both served minority audiences and were both cancelled far before their time. The Hour felt like a show better-suited for BBC Four in its premise; its execution, of course, was thrilling and heart-breaking all at once, using a young, fresh cast to sell itself to a younger audience. It found its popularity as a show for women, many connecting with Bel Rowley, the show's lead. It was leagues better than current popular historical dramas; The Musketeers, for example, has a fun, bubbly atmosphere - but comparing the two is like comparing Jamie Oliver and McDonalds. Sure, I enjoy McDonalds, but I wouldn't want it for my last meal on earth. And if I had to pick a historical drama show, I would rather have one more series of The Hour than three more series of a show that treats women as so disposable that female characters are frequently introduced and then killed off again in the space of an episode.   [caption id="attachment_118965" align="aligncenter" width="640"]   In the Flesh served a minority, under-represented audience just as much as The Hour did. BBC Three's zombie show, however, was far more popular; whilst viewing figures were comparatively lower (which makes sense, considering BBC Three isn't a terrestrial channel), the online response to In the Flesh has been explosive. At the end of last year it beat Sherlock (arguably the most popular drama show on the British television at the moment) to win Radio Times' '2014 TV Show Champion' poll. On the evening of the show's cancellation, #RenewInTheFlesh trended world-wide, which is certainly no easy feat. Petitions asking online services such as Netflix and Amazon to pick up the show have got thousands of signatures. So why, really, was the show cancelled? Other than those pesky hard choices, of course. The truth of it is that the BBC has a hit-and-miss relationship with young audiences. In terms of drama shows, the BBC has taken a tactic of 'throw everything at a problem and see what sticks', and if the viewing figures don't add up, the show's gone. Whilst funding is also a key issue - in 2010, the BBC licence fee was frozen for six years, leading to a cut in funds of 16% across the board - the BBC's attitude to its shows is more problematic than the lack of funds. With the slew of cancellations of diverse, challenging shows, the BBC is revealing an inherent lack of trust in its original drama. You only have to look at previous programmes to see the difference; this trust gave Being Human five series, despite a marked decrease in quality in the last few series. Yet now a similar supernaturally-themed show can barely get off the ground, simply because the BBC is no longer willing - or, perhaps, able - to give its shows the time to flourish.
The BBC is no longer willing - or, perhaps, able - to give its shows the time to flourish.
If the BBC wants to continue to create challenging, innovative shows for young people, it should learn that the nature of the way audiences (particularly younger audiences, for whom the inevitable Netflix bell always tolls) watch television is changing and adapt with it. But, more importantly, it should learn to trust good talent and ensure that minority audiences are being served in a world where the media leaves them vastly under-represented or reduced to a comic-effect side character. But all is not lost. If you find yourself still in need of your zombie fix, BBC Three has a new reality television show out. It's a reality game show called I Survived a Zombie Apocalypse. It's got Greg James in it. It's got all the ingredients to be absolute, coma-inducing crap. But BBC Three schedulers can shove it in between Snog Marry Avoid and Sun, Sex and Suspicious Parents and sit back, happy in the knowledge that they've, once again, done the absolute minimum to provide young audiences with diverse, challenging television.
